div.head: The Answer thereto.
div.p: His Highness leaveth the Colloquie to proceed if they please; and (if cause shal then appear,) from what shall be by them done, his Highness will give redress, such as shall be just.

closer.signed: Signed. Nath. Bacon, Master of Requests.

div.p:
By the contents of which Petition, and his Highness Answer thereto, we appeal to the Courteous Reader; whither the Petitioners, (who were but a part of the said Congregation,) are not by their own shewing, rebellious, and disobedient to, and against our Ecclesiastical Government. And have (as much as in them lay,) endeavoured to abuse his Highness, by suggesting, that a Coetus of all the Strangers Churches in London, is impowered, and constituted to decide their differences, by the Charter of Edward the sixth: Whereas by the very thing it self, there is no such matter, (as is before expressed,) the words of the Patent being,) That the Patentees be suffered freely, and quietly to have, enjoy, use, and exercise their own proper Rites, and Ceremonies, and their own proper, and peculiar Ecclesiastical Discipline. Nor is there in that Patent, the least shadow of the constitution of a Coetus; Our Government being intrinsecally within our selves, of the several French Churches in England; And so hath been for about these eighty yeers: and no way commixed with the Dutch, or any other Strangers Churches. Nor doe we contest for any more Liberty, then what hath been for so many Succession of years accustomed.
In so much that we have had 29 Colloquies of all our Churches, as occasion immerged: Of which the Reader will have a more exact account in this Treatise. And if Mr. Delmey, or any other of our Church, should have consented to have any difference decided, by any other power, then our Colloquie; certainly they must needs have contracted a very heavy guilt upon their Consciences; When as we are all obliged by solemn promisses, in the presence of God, to maintein our Discipline, and Government, as it hath been for so many years established in our Churches.

And as to the Colloquie, mentioned in the said Petition, which convened 10 January, 1655. We have given the Reader a full account before; How that by the undue practises of the Consistory of London, they were dissolved without acting any thing at all. And had not our Petitions been worthy of reception, We conceive, his Highness would not have been so fauourably pleased to answer them, by granting our Requests; and in plain words to deny the Consistories Petition, by confirming ours therein also: as by his Highness Answer may appear. And to pass by those Petitioners hard Censures, and expressions of us, and their endeavours to
have a Synod of the Dutch, and French Colloquies in England; because they pretend, the French Colloquie consists but of few persons, some whereof are partiall; We shall onely intimate to the Reader, the Consistories grand defection from their Brethren; And positively to assert, That there are now more Deputies in capacity, to meet in Colloquie of the French Churches in England, then formerly were, or could be assembled: In respect our Churches are increased, to almost double the number, which was about 20, or 30 yeers agone.

And we shall herein further demonstrate, and prove, that the commixing, and conjoining of a Synod, composed of the Dutch Colloquie, and the French, (in the prayer of the said Petition mentioned, to be according to our Discipline;) is altogether inconsistent with, and different from our Discipline: And that the Churches of the Dutch, and French Nations, are not all the Strangers Churches now in England; (as the said Petitioners pretend. Whereby we conceive, that the Reader will positively conclude, that the Consistory of London, hath prevaricated, and again, (as they did before concerning the Caetus, and the Patent of Edward the sixt,) endeavoured to misinform his Highness; And
upon consideration of our proofs, and assertions, will benignely interpret our proceedings, in labouring to conserve our own Discipline, and Government.

But as touching the Certificate, so often mentioned, and repeated in the said Petition, to be given by the Coetus; The same is, and hath been so privately kept, and concealed from us by the Petitioners, and their party: That for as much as we have had no Copy thereof: We can give no Answer thereunto.

But to continue a Method, and Series of transactions, the Reader shall understand, that after the Consistory of London did preferre the last recited Petition to his Highness, and were repulsed; They nevertheless attempted 6. August, 1656, to misinforme his Highness again: And therefore Mr. Stouppe, with six Elders, and four Deacons of the Consistory, (unexpected by the Fathers of Families,) had audience before his Highness at Whitehall: Where, four of the said Fathers, happening to be by Providence, were also admitted to his Highness presence: Before whom, Mr. Stouppe complained against the appointed Convention of the Colloquie, 22. August following, Charging the Deputies with partiality, and pressing with much importunity,
that the differences might be decided by the Dutch, and themselves in Coetus, (as the natural Judges:) But his Highness, hearing our Defence, Ordered that the Colloquie should proceed; and if they could not end the differences, He would appoint ten, or twelve Godly Divines, of the English Nation to determine the same: Unto which, (being by Mr. Stouppe's own proposition,) both parties submitted. But the Consistory being still restless, and designing, (as much as in them lay,) either to prevent the meeting of the Colloquie, or render Mr. Delmey, and our selves, to them, and all the world, as culpable, and offensive persons; Did therefore publish in French, and English, (without the consent of the Dutch Consistory,) the said Libellous Pamphlet.

And since we have used all the aforesaid means, for a Reconciliation between the Consistory, and our selves, (as by all the fore-recited passages, and papers will appear,) according to the Government of our Churches, and for the preservation thereof; And if the Reader please to consider our Petitions to his Highness, and the Petition of the Consistory, and their Actings, and Obstructions endeavoured against us; It will manifestly appear to his Judgement, that we have onely insisted
to maintein our Church Government, and to keep unity, and order therein; And whither the Pamphlettors be any better, than such persons, as they, pag. 22. doe labour to disprove themselves to be, viz. Abominable persons, and Libertines: When as, they did actually suspend Mr. Delmey for preaching against holy daies, and for the Doctrine of Repentance, as is before proved in the Report to his Highness before mentioned: And when as pag. 24. they in some manner confess, that Holy daies were abolisht by our Colloquie in the year 1644. Which we affirme was done accordingly; and also by another in the year, 1654.

At all which unreasonable proceedings of the Consistory, the Reader shall not need to admire; if he seriously consider, with what disrespect, and unnatural declension, they desert our Government by Colloquies, so long used, and continued in our Churches; So that in their Pamphlet, pag. 23. they doe onely, and that very carelesly, make mention of a Colloquie; As if it were but some small part, or rather none at all, of our Church-Government, or not worthy to be mentioned with respect; And that although Mr. Delmey appealed to a Colloquie in 1655; And because, it never was held; therefore
his appeal should be void: Which is a Consequent so incongruous, and inconsistent to, and with the natural constitution of all Courts, and Conventions for Appeals, as also of our Colloquies themselves, that it cannot be deduced in equity, or good Conscience: For then it would evene, that if there should be a Determination, and cessation of Appeals by the Non-convention of the persons, appointed in chief to judge; the Consciences, as well as the Estates of the Appellants, should be subjected to the fatal inconveniences of unjust, and arbitrary Sentences, by a meer circumstance of time. And whereas they mention, pag. 23. That in the intervals of Colloquies, the power of Censures should be in the Consistory; It is objected to the Readers Judgement, how weak, and unreasonable their inference is: As if the general standing Rules of our Discipline, and acts of Colloquies, had not provided for the good Government of the Churches, in the vacancy of Colloquies; But that yet, the power of judging should be left to the discretion of the Consistory, after an appeal made from them to a Colloquie. Whereby it will not, nor can be denyed; But that the Consistory have been more willing, and propense to usurpe to themselves a power, and Jurisdiction over Mr.
Delmey, and others; which did not, nor doth it belong to any others whatsoever, but to our Colloquies themselves; As hereafter will more fully appear.

And whereas in the last page of their Pamphlet, the Authors appeal to their Readers Judgement, whither upon Consideration of their Proceedings, they will not judge Mr. Delmey, to be the Author of all the troubles of our Church, and that they have most justly suspended him from the exercise of his charge amongst them, for the Causes by them specified: We likewise fly to the Judgement of all impartial men; whither, upon their serious revise, and perusal of this Tractate, and our manifest producing, and stating our passages, and papers, from the first unhappy contest, to this present; As before, and hereafter they will plainly see; That the Consistory of London, have designed any thing more, then to advance themselves, (contrary to our Discipline,) into a Superiority above the common order, and custome of their Brethren of the other Churches: And out of a Spirit of arrogance, and contempt of them, do disesteem, and undervalue them, as poor, and of little number, and accompt in this Nation: Whereas we affirme again, that we were never more in number, and to be considerably
acccompted, then at present: as hereafter will also more plainly appear.

Now in the last place, we find an Appendix made to the said Pamphlet in English; Wherein the Consistory have been as disingenuous, and partial, as they have been in all the premisses, submitted to publique Construction: And they therein set down, under a glossy Title, Acts of the Colloquie of the French Churches assembled at London, August, 22. 1656. And at a morning Session, Friday September 12. to be made for the composure of our affairs: But in respect Mr. Delmey rejected the sentence of the Colloquie, he had himself desired with so much ardor; and proceeded more than ever in clamors, and Calumnies against the Consistory; They therefore divulged those Acts: For ground whereof, It is pretended, that the Assembly seeing, that after their often exhortations to Mr. Delmey to appear, and complain against the Church of London; he persisted obstinately not to own the Colloquie, (though he promised submission thereto;) they thereupon proceeded, as the Consistory had before done against him. To which it is answered, That as the Consistory had all along before, extrajudicially acted against Mr. Delmey; So likewise did not those persons, by
the unfitting practices of the Consistory, permit the Colloquie to constitute orderly, and as of ancient, and common right, they ought to have done. Nor do the Pamphlettors assert, that it was a Colloquie according to the Orders, and directions of his Highness, and Discipline of the Churches; (there being but two lawful Deputies to compose the same, As further will be evidenced:) Yet notwithstanding, that in all the Series of the said Pamphlet, the Authors before presume to take upon themselves an absolute, and independent power to censure Mr. Delmey, by part of their Consistory, of themselves Simply, and divided; Now, the Reader may observe, that for the justification of themselves against Mr. Delmey, the Authors solely resort to, and build upon the Acts, pretended to be well made by that Assembly; although they were never regularly constituted.

And next, we shall offer to the Readers Judgement, the Act of Discipline of all the French Churches in England: which now stands in force, and ought to be observed by them: The words whereof are, as followeth, viz.

div.head: Of Colloquies, and Assemblies Generall.
div.p: FOR the better mainteining of purity of life, and Doctrine, and together, Order, and union of the Churches; There shall be from year to year, or at other convenient time, one Assembly of all the Deputies of all the French Churches, that are in this Kingdom. And every Church shall send one Minister, and one Elder, furnished with Memorials, and Instructions, approved, and signed by the Consistory. Nevertheless, without taking away the Liberty of the Minister, and Elder to propound of themselves, what they shall think expedient. These are the very words of the Discipline: Which will evince the truth, That that Assembly 22 August, 1656. were not a lawful Colloquie; And therefore, and upon the ground of the said Act of our Discipline, The Fathers of Families of the French Church London, in behalf of themselves, and many other Members, humbly petitioned his Highness the Lord Protector, in the words following, viz.

THat your Petitioners have formerly made their humble Addresses to your Highness, in behalf of Mr. Delmey, (their faithful, and Godly Minister,) who is unjustly suspended from his Ministery in that Church; and also in behalf of divers members thereof: And thereupon your Highness graciously referred all differences, to a Colloquie of all the French Churches: And upon hearing, both parties, confirmed it; Proposing, that if an end was not made by the Colloquie, that your Highness would appoint ten, or twelve Godly Divines of this Nation, to make a final Determination. To which all parties consented.

Since which, all endeavours have been made to call a Colloquie of all the French Churches in the Nation, according to your Higness said Grant: All appeared: Two Deputies of each Church were sent: The Deputies of three Churches first arrived, (being sixe persons:) Four of them onely assumed the power of a Colloquie, though not all capable to sit in Colloquie; Neither have they formerly: And after the two other Churches were admitted Judges, they deprived them from acting: And several times refused to call the other Churches absent, (as accustomed;
(And when they came, rejected them also, (except those of Dover:) Albeit one of them was a Delinquent in Armes, and departed the City upon your Highness last Proclamation: And thereby, five persons onely, assumed to make a Colloquie, contrary to our Discipline: By combination with some of the Consistory of London, (also disaffected,) that thereby they might keep all power in themselves; The better to maintein their unjust proceedings, formerly complained of; And the more to oppress Mr. Delmey, (by engaging him against his Conscience,) and others, who stand well affected to Reformation; In contempt of your Highness Order, and Proposals: Which they have disobeyed; and questioned your power, by Censuring some for submitting thereunto: On purpose to frustrate your pious Inclinations to Justice, and peace.

Which irregular proceedings, have been disapproved of by the Deputies of the three other Churches, (being sixe persons;) As by their Certificate annexed may appear; and also by the Consistory of the Church in Norwich; (As by their Letter annexed appeareth;) Who sent two of those five Deputies, that irregularly acted, as aforesaid: Whereby no Colloquie hath been convened, according to your Highness Order, and the Discipline of the
Churches; and thereby no end of the differences is made.

Wherefore Your Petitioners humbly pray your Highness graciously to Order, that such a Number of Godly Divines, of this Nation, (As Your Highness shall think fit,) may hear, and determine the Differences; As was submitted unto before Your Highness: Impowering them to summon all parties, and witnesses, with such Books, and Papers, as shall be expedient; That Mr. Delmey, and the Members well affected, may not be oppresse • in their Consciences; But be protected from Injury, and enjoy the Gospell in its purity, and the Church setled in peace.

closer.signed: And your Petitioners, (as in duty bound,) shall ever pray, &c.

div.p: Here followeth the Certificate of the sixe Deputies, (in the said Petition mentioned,) Translated out of the Originall in French, viz.

div.head: London, the 18th. of September, 1656.
div.p:
VVE under-written Ministers, and Elders, Deputed from three of the French Churches here in England; namely, of Thorney Abbey, Canterbury, and Santhoff; Who have endeavoured to constitute a compleat Colloquie, of the Deputies of all the French Churches within this Nation; to end, (through the help of God,) the troublesome differences of the French Church of London, and to establish in it a good, and permanent peace: But that taking no effect; (though all the Deputies of all the said Churches, were at the same time in the said City,) being met together; And having also in our company, Mr. Crespine, (lately one of the Ministers of the Church of Canterbury:) And being desired to give our Advice, and Sense, (according to the Word of God, the Rule, and practice of the Reformed Churches, and specially, of the French Churches in this Nation,) Upon several difficulties,
and Questions, propounded to Us; In all Candour, and sincerity, have answered: as followeth,

div.head: Question.
div.p: Whither a Consistory have in it self, authority, and power, to Interdict their Pastor, from the Exercise of his Charge: And to publish such an interdiction to the People; without calling before hand, two, or three Ministers, (not suspected,) to help the said Consistory; especially, when the • e is nothing against the life, and Doctrine of the Minister.

div.head: Answer.
div.p:
We answer, That according to the Discipline of the Reformed Churches, a Consistory hath not that power, and Authority to interdict their Pastour, from the exercise of his Charge, for any fault whatsoever; without the help of two, or three Pastors, (not suspected;) much less, to publish the said interdiction; specially, when he hath appealed to a Colloquie; which ought to determine differences, that cannot be ended in the Consistory. Now, the Interdiction of a Minister, is one of the weightiest Difficulties, and wherein a Consistory ought not to precipitate it self. Lastly, there being
nothing against the life, or Doctrine of the Minister: And having appealed from the Sentence of the Consistory to the Colloquie: It is evident, he cannot be condemned of Rebellion against Ecclesiasticall Order. And that there is no sufficient Cause of interdiction, We have shewed this by Rule, and Example, in our ancient Colloquies.

div.head: Question.
div.p: If we can allow of a Consistories gathering of the people together, to dishonor their Pastour, and make him contemptible amongst them.

div.head: Answer.
div.p: We answer, that such a kind of proceeding is altogether unheard of in the Reformed Churches. That it is altogether contrary to Discipline; which doth not permit the debates of Consistory to be divulged to the multitude: Seeing also, the whole matter was referred to the Colloquie; the judgement whereof was to be expected. Adde, that this is enervating, and takeing away the whole efficacy of the Ministery of the said Pastour, before a finall judgment: And against Charity to spread the evills, (if any there were,) And to cause it to break out beyond its limits, instead of covering it.

div.head: Question.
div.p:
If a Colloquie, (being appointed by the Supreme
Magistrate, for the deciding of certain differences, arisen in a Church, between two several parties;) one of the parties doth well to print a Book, with an intent to publish it in time, to stain, and blemish the reputation of the other party; before the decision of the said Colloquie.

div.head: Answer.
div.p: We answer, That this kind of proceeding is much more to be rejected, and blame-worthy, than the former: For it tends to the defaming of persons throughout the whole world; yea, even amongst Infidels, and Enemies of the Church of Christ; and to fill all with scandals, and open the mouth of Adversaries to evil speaking. It is against all charity, and Piety; telling the debates of Brethren in Gath, and to publish them in the streets of Askelon: To the end, that the Daughters of the Philistines may rejoice, and the Daughters of the uncircumcised triumph.

div.head: Question.
div.p: If a Consistory may condemn their Pastour for his manner of preaching, without specifying wherein?

div.head: Answer.
div.p: Such a general Condemnation, without specification, taketh away from the Pastor, the m • ans of defending himself, or correcting hims • lf, in case, he hath failed.

div.head: Question.
div.p: Whither these Propositions, A Minister must not alwaies preach the threats of the Law: And Ministers ought some times to preach the Threats of the Law, and some times the Promises of the Gospell, be contradictory.

div.head: Answer.
div.p: It is clear, there is no contradiction between them; and that they perfectly agree together.

div.head: Question.
div.p: Whither it falling out to treat of the one, and twentieth Section of the Catechisme, where it is said, That God will not be served according to our Phantasie, but his pleasure: It be not convenient to speak against humane Traditions, and voluntary service?

div.head: Answer.
div.p: It is very requisite to be done; And this is onely to treat of the Subject of the Section.

div.head: Question.
div.p:
The Churches being seven, and there being but four met, (whereof the one is party,) And the other three remaining have but five Votes;
Because one of the said Churches hath been deprived of one of her votes; Whither such a Company ought to be held for a lawfull Colloquie, to decide differences of great difficulty; especially, when against the ordinary practice, they have refused to write to the Churches absent?

div.head: Answer.
div.p: It is the Practice of our Churches, when they are met, to write to the Churches absent, to induce them to send their Deputies; especially when Businesses are of great weight. And seeing, there never were more Churches of our Language in this Countrey, then now: And never a lesser Company of Deputies, then at this time, to compose a Colloquie: We judge, that such a small number of persons, ought not to have undertaken the decision of such difficulties, as did offer themselves; without endeavouring by their Letters, to strengthen themselves with the Deputies of other Churches: And when those Deputies were arrived, they ought not to have refused to adde them to their company; To the intent, they should together compose a Colloquie of the Deputies of all the Churches, of our Language in this Countrey.

Having seen the printed Acts of the Consistory, and of the Coetus of London, (unto which Mr. Delmey hath declared himself, not able to acquiesce,) And the profers in writing made by the said Mr. Delmey, drawing neer the said Acts: We judge, that it was a great wrong, offered to him by the Consistory, to interdict him of the exercise of his ministery; By reason that he could not acquiesce in the said Acts: And so to put that dishonour upon him, and procure that Damage to the Church.

We judge also, That the said French Consistory of London, hath failed in setting up the publick exercises on Holy daies; Seeing, that is forbidden to all the Churches of our Language, in this Country, by our Colloquies from the year, 1644.

div.p: Here followeth, also the Letter from the Consistory of the Church of Norwich, mentioned in the said Petition, Translated also out of French.

body.head: Norwich, 15 September. 1656.
body.p:
VVE are informed, You have refused to call the Deputies of the other French Churches to you in Colloquie; and that the Deputies of Canterbury, have but one Vote between them both. These things we apprehend to be utterly contrary to our Discipline, and Constitution of our Colloquies. Sirs, We desire, Our Deputies should forthwith return to Norwich, by reason of the great expences We are at; and because there is no great hopes of doing any good, toward a Peace of the Churches; by reason of the Irregularity: And also, because our antient Pastour, the Doctor De Laune, can no longer exercise the function of the Ministery, by reason of his great Age, and Weakness of Body: Nevertheless, It hath pleased God, that of late we have seen him, and heard him in the Pulpit, and in the Celebration of the Holy Sacraments of Our LORD; to our great
Joy, and comfort, and peace: Which peace we wish unto you all, and rest, your Servants, who desire, and pray for peace among you all; Abiding yours, and in the Name of all.

div.p: We desire no alteration in the Holy Supper of the Lord, while our Churches are in trouble.
To our honoured Brethren, the Gentlemen, Ministers, and Elders, met in Colloquie, in LONDON.
To which last mentioned Petition, Certificate, and Letter, his Highness was graciously pleased to return this Answer:

body.p:
WE having been appealed unto by divers Members of the French Church, residing in London, concerning some supposed injury, done them by the Consistory; Which doth more plainly appear by a Petition preferred unto US, by the parties complaining: which WE have herewith sent you: Unto which the said Consistory have put in their Answer; And the Complainants have replyed: which papers also WE herewith send you: And perceiving, the taking the proofs, and stating the whole business, will ask more time, then WE can afford: And being willing, the said matters in question may be composed according to equity: WE have thought fit, and doe hereby referre the said business unto you, or any three, or more of you, to hear what both parties have to say for the making good their matters: Who have promised US, to attend you therein: That so, when you shall have soe heard the same, you may report back
unto US the state of the business; together with your opinion thereupon.

closer.dateline: Given at Whitehall the last day of October, 1656.

div.p: Now for the further satisfaction of the Reader, We shall also give relation, of the Sense of the Consistory of the Church of Canterbury; As by an Extract of the Articles of the Walloon Consistory in Canterbury; of the 19th. and 22••. of October, 1656. Translated out of French, appears; As followeth.

The Company of the Walloon Consistory of Canterbury, (with the Deacons,) having heard the Rehearsall of the things, past among the Deputies of our Churches, which met at London the 22 of August last, and the daies following; having also seen the Acts of the Consistory, and also of the Coetus of London; Unto which the approbation, and acquiescing of Mr Delmey hath been required: And the offers that
the said Mr. Delmey hath made to the said Consistory, conteined in three propositions; having also seen the pretended Sentence of the pretended Colloquie, against the said Mr. Delmey; which was published in the Pulpi • , one Lords day in the morning, by Mr. Stouppe; though it had not heen intimated before to the said Mr. Delmey; and no advertisement was given unto him of the publishing thereof. These things maturely considered; And after the calling upon the Name of God, the Company judgeth, and declareth.
1. Not to acknowledge, nor to be able to acknowledge, that there hath been a lawful Colloquie, among the said Deputies; to iudge of the Differences of the Church of London.

1. Because, (contrary to the Discipline of our Churches,) Mr. Du Perrier, was there admitted, as Pastour; Who never received the Imposition of hands, in the reformed Churches; And hath no oth • r Ordination, but that of a Priest in the Romish Church.

2. Because, having (after a deliberate Consideration of all things,) expressly admitted our Deputies, as Judges of the difference of London; They have afterwards, (without cause,) taken away one of
their Votes to please the Consistory of London, and to blemish our Church, by maiming it: For the which cause, we have commanded our Deputies to withdraw from such a Company: Or not to sit, but with right to complain, of such an unrighteousness to the next Colloquie.

3. Because also, they were not a sufficient number to compose a Colloquie, to judge of matters of so great Importance: For, of seven Churches of our language in this Land, there were at the first, onely the Deputies of two Churches: viz. of Norwich, and Southampton; (whereof one was the aforesaid Mr. Du Perrier:) who have undertaken to judge, as having an authority of a Colloquie. Afterwards, their number was increased by one Deputy of Dover; (For the Elder was constreined to withdraw, by reason of the Proclamation of his Highness the Lord Protector, concerning those that have been in armes against the State.) They, at the Conclusion of their Assembly, have added to themselves, a private Person of the Church of Dover; who was then in London; but without Letters; and without the choice, and knowledge of the said Church: Which is altogether extravagant.

4. Because, they have refused from the beginning
of their meeting, to write to the Churches absent, to exhort them to come, according to the practice in such a Case: As appeareth by the Colloquie in the year, 1647.

5. Finally, and most of all; because, when the Deputies of the other Churches were come, and there was a possibility to compose a Colloquie, of all the Deputies of our Churches: And notice of it, being given unto them; they have the very next day with-drawn; flying, and shuning all Communion, and correspondence with their Brethren. Whence, it doth appear, that that company was notoriously factious, and did not seek the peace of the Churches: But onely to oppose one party, to please the other. For at least, they were to shew the other Deputies, what they had done, that they might have their advise.
2. The said Company of the Consistory, (with the Deacons of Canterbury,) judgeth, and declareth; That Mr. Delmey hath been unjustly interdicted, and without cause, by the French Consistory of London.

1. Because a Consistory hath not that Authority, (according to our Discipline,) to interdict a Pastour, for any cause whatsoever; without calling first, two or three Pastours,
(not suspected;) which hath not been done by the Consistory of London.

2. Because the non-acquiescence to those three Acts of the said Consistory, or of the Coetus, is no cause for the suspension of a Pastour; Who is of singular edification to the Church; and in whose life, and doctrine his greatest enemies have nothing to upbraid him with.
3. Because Mr. Delmey by his Offers, in three Propositions, satisfieth abundantly to the Discipline, and to all, what the Consistory might justly require of him in this matter.

4. Because by the refusal of the proffers of Mr. Delmey, the Consistory of London giveth occasion to think, that they are not contented with the Word of God, and the Discipline; and that they will establish themselves Judges above the word of God; and that they will not give the Liberty unto Mr. Delmey, to preach against all manner of Errors, and Vices, without respect of persons; But that they will oppress Mr. Delmey in his Conscience, and take away from him the Liberty, due to every Minister of the Gospel.

Therefore, seeing the said Deputies have approved all the proceedings of the Consistory of London: And have appointed, (as we conceive,)
that their pretended Sentence should be publickly read in the Pulpit, (without being made known before hand to Mr. Delmey;) They have manifestly declared themselves partial, and unjust against our Discipline. And our most humble, and ardent desire is, that it would please his Highness the Lord Protector, to take the cause in hand, and to deliver the oppressed, and all our Churches, from this Tyranny; according to the example of the good Christian Emperors; Wherein his Highness shall not prejudice our Discipline; But rather shall establish it against the design of those, who seek to overthrow it.
