div.p:
And further to justifie, and maintein the Opinion, and Judgement of the Officers in Consistory of the said Church in Canterbury, and also of the Reverend English Divines,
(hereafter declared,) We shall here insert some Acts of our Colloquies, antient, and modern, instead of many others which we might produce: Whereby we hope, the Reader will evidently discern, That the Suspension of Mr. Delmey is altogether unjust, and unwarrantable; And that all the specious pretences of the Pamphlettors, are fictitious and delusory: And therefore we shall render the Translation of those Acts, out of French, as followeth.

div.head: Colloquie the tenth.
div.p: The Articles of Colloquie of the French Churches, gathered in this Kingdome, held in Norwich, the 25th. of April, and other daies following▪ in the year of our Lord, 1593. In which, (after the Invocation of the Name of God,) Mr. Lescailiet was chosen to moderate the Action, and Phillip de la Motte, for Scribe.

div.head: Article the first.
div.p:
Upon the Appeal of the Brother Mr. Nicholas Bayard, and his rejecting of the Sentence of the Consistory of the Church of Norwich, for his Suspension from the holy Sacrament; and appearing before the Colloquie: All things having been seriously examined on all sides,
the final Sentence was pronounced unto the said Brother Bayard, and unto the Consistory of the said Church. That on the one side, the Brother Bayard had not a sufficient Foundation, upon which he could build an assured right upon the Church of Norwich; and that he had greatly forgotten himself in his Outrages, with many Defamations against all the Congregation, in a publick Sermon, to the Scandal of good people; Notwitstanding the uncertainty of his pretended Right: And is required to desist in his demand, and confess his having offended God, and the Church. On the other side, that the Consistory, (having sent the Judgment to the people; An action doubtful! without endeavouring a Friendly Communication with the said Bayard to give him content: And it being too much to precipitate, to give Sentence of Suspension against a Minister of the Word, without calling some other Pastours of other Churches, and to call him, or them more than one time to their company;) shall be admonished to take off • he said Suspension; So as Bayard confesseth his fault; They giving him some reasonable recompence, in consideration that he was mistaken, and overtaken by those, that were in charge in the Church, seven years since, for to hold him tyed, and in Suspence, without giving him any assurance of mutuall
Obligation. To this Judgement all have acquiesced so well, that the above said suspension was taken off; And being reconciled, have given hands one to the other, in witnesse of their mutuall brotherly union. The Papers, and Acts of this difference, and many dependances more, amply set forth, have been delivered into the hands of the Brethren of Hampton, by the advise of the Company of the said Colloquie.

div.head: The second Act of the said Colloquie.
div.p: If a Minister be convicted of Enormous, and notorious crimes, He shall be suddenly deposed by the Consistory, (they having called two, or three Pastors, not suspested.) And in case, that the Delinquent complain of the witnesses, or of Calumnie: The fact shall be reported to the Colloquie: And if he hath preached, or taught hereticall Doctrines, he shall suddenly be suspended by the Consistory; (two, or three Ministers being called, as above;) untill that the Colloquie hath ended the same. As for the cause of his deposition, that shall not be declared to the people; If the necessity doe not require it: Of which the Consistory shall judge.

div.head: Colloquie 27. in the year, 1646. Assembled in London. Friday 31. July, Article 65.

p.hi: Upon the question, what formality is to be observed by a Church, which doth pretend to have something to object against its Pastour, in regard of Doctrine, or in regard of carriage: It hath been answered in such Case; If the Consistory cannot have assistance of neighbour-Pastours, They shall give advise of their griefs to the Sister-Churches, for to proceed the more safe, untill a final decision by the Colloquie.

div.p:
And now we doubt not, but these Acts, and Resolutions of our Colloquies, will fully satisfie the judicious Reader; And for the truth thereof, We appeal to all the French Churches in England, whither they are not in force, and unrepealed: And as we are informed, the Dutch Consistory in London, (assisted with other Deputies of some other of the Dutch-Churches,) have very lately proceeded in the same manner, in a Difference
depending in the Dutch Church in Sandwich. And therefore, as to the French Consistory of London's Actions against Mr. Delmey, We shall leave them to be compared, and commensurated, by the Scale, and Ballance of the Readers Impartiall Judgement.

Upon which Reference of his Highness to the s • id Divines of the English Nation; They fully heard both parties, and all their Allegations, and proofs; And as to their Judgements, and Opinions concerning the said Colloquie, They reported to his Highness their Sense, in or about 19. June, 1657. (after a long time in attending the Consistorie's producing their Papers, and making their Defence,) in this manner: That they did humbly certifie; That as to the Constitution of the late Colloquie, (called by his Highness Order,) upon the Petition of the Fathers of Families and complained of by the said Fathers of Families, in their papers to his Highness; That according to the Discipline of the said Churches, a Colloquie is to consist of all the French Churches in this Nation: a Minister, and an Elder from every Church. And they found by the book of Colloquies, that in seventy sixe years, the Churches have called twenty nine Colloquies: In seven of which the Deputies of all the Churches, (except one,) appeared;
And the absent Churches questioned, and censured; Though it is said, the absence was occasioned, partly by the Bishop of Norwich; and partly by reason, that two successive Ministers in Hampton, were much, and long afflicted with the Gout, and so could not travel: In three other Colloquies, the Deputies of all the Churches met, (except one Elder,) for which the Church was censured: And in all the other nineteen Colloquies, all the Deputies of all the French Churches were present: But in this last Colloquie, (though there be seven Churches of the French Nation in England,) the Referrees found but five Deputies in all, (besides the Deputies of the Church in London, which were the Parties complainned of,) that is to say, from Norwich two, from Hampton two, and from Dover one: For the Elder from Dover, having been a Delinquent in Arms, left the Citty within a day, or two after he came, upon his Highness Proclamation: The Deputies of Canterbury, (having sate in the beginning of the Colloquie; And having one of their Votes injuriously taken from them; And an Order being made, that they should have but one Vote between them,) with-drew from the Assembly, before the Deputies of Dover came to Town; And were not afterwards admitted to sit in Colloquie:
And the Deputies of Santhoff, and Thorney Abbey not comeing in time, sate not at all; The Colloquie first refusing to write to them to come, as hath been used in former Colloquies, (though they were desired so to doe by the Fathers of Families;) And then at last dissolving themselves in hast, just that night, that those Deputies came to Town. On all which proceedings the Deputies of London, (who are parties) are thought to have a great Influence; Mr. Cisner, (the man most complained of,) being for the most part present in, and Moderator of the Assemhly: And of those five persons that sate, two of them, to wit, the Deputies of the Church of Norwich were sent for home by their Consistory; who disapproved of the Acts of that Colloquie, as being contrary to their Discipline, and the constitution of their Colloquies. And the Minister of Hampton, having been a Priest in the Church of Rome, and not since Ordeined in any Reformed Church, (For ought appears in their Papers,) was not capable by their Discipline to sit in Colloquie. Notwithstanding which, that Colloquie took upon them, to make Acts in Confirmation of the aforesaid Acts of the Consistory in London, to censure the Fathers of Families, for submitting to His
Highness's Proposition of referring their Differences to English Ministers; And to admit of the Observation of Holy daies, contrary to former Acts of Colloquie, &c. So as the Referrees unanimously did conceive, that that Colloquie was neither rightly constituted, nor did regularly act according to their Discipline.

And the Reader may also take notice, that Mr. Cisner was President, for the most part, of that pretended Colloquie, (Being the party most complained against:) And albeit, that he is not yet rightfully ordeined, according to our Discipline; (As he hath lately confessed:) In like manner as the Minister of Southampton is not, (who hath been a Romish Priest.) And also, being desired by the Deputies, and Fathers of Families, (upon the first Assembling of those Deputies,) that a Fast might be kept for humiliation of the Church; Mr. Cisner uncharitably answered, That Hypocrites, (when they had any wickednesse
to Act,) would keep a Fast: And the Dutch also, by two of their Elders, requested the same; Offering for that purpose, to keep a Fast the same day in their Church: But the Consistory of London refused, contrary to severall Acts of our Colloquies, and former experiences, and common practices.

Upon the consideration of which last mentioned Petition, Certificate, and other Proofs, and the Reference from, and Report to his Highness; Whereby not onely his Highness did declare his Judgment: But the said seven English Divines, did unanimously agree, that upon matter of fact, aswell as right, the said Colloquie was not rightly constituted, nor did regularly act; It will be satisfactorie, and sufficient enough, That the said Consistory, and all their proceedings have been arbitrary, and usurped: And that Mr. Delmey, and the Fathers of Families have been wrongfully abused, and injured: And that they ought to be justly vindicated, aswell in respect of themselves, as the generall Discipline of all the Churches: So that Mr. Delmey, may no longer be obstructed from the Exercise of his Charge: But have liberty to preach in that Church, without impediment, or any violence offered to him: And the Fathers of Families, (who
have been wrongfully suspended,) may enjoy his Ministery in all the parts thereof, with all such as will walk regularly, and according to the Word of God, and Discipline: For that, (as by the said last recited Petition appears,) Aswell the sixe persons, (being Ministers, and Elders,) who were elected, and sent for Deputies to the said Assembly; as also the Consistories of the Churches in Norwich, and Canterbury have, (as aforesaid,) disapproved, and disowned the Actions, (as irregular,) of the other five persons, as to their Constitution of a Colloquie; as also the Proceedings of the Consistory of London, as being contrary to the Discipline of all the French Churches in England.

And furthermore, whereas in the Conclusion of the said Appendix to that Pamplet, the Authors alleadge, That Mr. Delmey hath rejected their Acts of Colloquie; aswell as he had slighted those of the Consistory, and of the Coetus; pretending many things to justifie his denyall of submission to them; Whose objections they had fully refuted; yet offering, If he find himself grieved by the Sentence of the Colloquie, (though he might be no more received to any Appeal, having slipped his time,) He shall have nevertheless
liberty to appeal to a Synod, assembled of the Dutch, and French Churches in England: Which he yet slights; Requiring to be judged by English Ministers: Whereto the Authours pretend they cannot consent, &c. To this We answer, That for the Reasons, and Relations before mentioned, Mr. Delmey cannot be thought, (without manifest wrong to his Conscience, and Infringing the Discipline, and Government of all the said French Churches,) to admit the said Assemblie to be a Colloquie, rightly constituted, and compounded; Nor can it be fairly objected against him, that he hath any waies slighted the Consistories Acts; otherwise, then by making a Just Appeal, to a lawfull Judicatorie from them; As by right he may, and ought to doe: And for the Acts of the Coetus, they are insignificant, and not obliging: In as much, as the Dutch Consistory disclaime any power over the French, either as joined with, or divided from them; Further then by a voluntary submission, and Consent of parties; Nor have they any more, or greater power, then English Ministers may have by such Condescension, and Agreament. Yet nevertheless the Pamphlettors
are so confident, (without any respect to their Brethren; Over whom they neither can, nor ought to be Superiours, without violating their Bond of Love, and Union,) to propose to Mr. Delmey, (As if they had some speciall power in themselves above all the rest of our Churches,) That he shall have liberty to appeal to a Synod of the Dutch, and French Churches. Whereas it cannot be denyed, But that the Dutch of London, are by profession, more enclined to the Actions of the Consistory, and have been much Contributory to them, by certifiing many things in their behalfe, (As the Pamplettors suggest,) for their advantage: And so in common equity, it cannot be demanded, That Mr. Delmey should submit to such Judges; If there were nothing to be pleaded by him for the antient Discipline, and Government of the French Churches apart, and distinctly by themselves. And for the Pamphlettors not submitting to English Ministers, it is very disingenuously insisted upon; Since that it is not without Precedent, that, (in Mr. Cisners own Case formerly,) Some Scotch, aswell as English Ministers interposed to accommodate some differences occasioned by him. And
moreover, (as by his Highness last Order of Reference, and other proofs, apppears;) the Consistory submitted willingly to his Highness said Referrees. Wherefore, notwithstanding the Pamphlettors great pretences, for the said Assemblies great care in making their pretended Acts, according to common Discipline, and Colloquies, and Consistorial Acts; Whereby they would vainly justifie, against palpaple Evidence of the contrary, their obstinate, and unwarrantable deportment towards Mr. Delmey, and the said Fathers of Families: Yet let the Reader courteously dijudicate, and distinguish upon all the Premisses; And we doubt not, but that the Innocence, and Justice of our Cause will be defended, and propugned by his judicious, and impartiall Censure. And that the Consistorie, or their Abettors, can in no wise fairly, and candidly answer, or positively deny these following Quaeres, which we, according to the constitutions of our Discipline, and Church Governement, by Acts of Colloquies, (not desiring to invade, or incroach upon the Liberties of any other persons, but to avouch, and maintein our own,) do offer, and propose to publick Consideration, as followeth:
1. Whither a Consistory of any of our Churches, ought to oppose the Assembling of a Colloquie, or Petition against it, according to the Discipline of our Churches in England?
2. Whither a Caetus hath power to judge, after an Appeal made to a Colloquie, without consent of parties?

3. Whither five persons can be a Colloquie for sixe Churches, when some of the Deputies are also incapable to sit in Colloquie; And others that are capable kept out; And the said five persons refused to write to the Churches absent: And when their proceedings are disavowed by one Consistory, which sent two of those five persons?
4. Whither a Caetus, or Synod with the Dutch, be any part of the French Discipline? And whither the French have any power, (in Church Government,) over the Dutch; or the Dutch over the French?
5. Whither a Consistory of themselves, have power to set up Holy Daies, After that they are abolished by several Colloquies of all the Churches.
6. Whither a Consistory of themselves; can cast out a Minister for any Cause whatever: And especially after he hath appealed to a Colloquie by their Consent.
7. Whither a Consistory can suspend from the Lords Supper, severall Members of their Church, for petitioning to the chief Magistrate to preserve their Church Government.
8, Whither a Consistory can put several Deacons out of the Consistory, because they would not retract their Appeal made to a Colloquie.

9. Whither five persons assembled, under the pretended form of a Colloquie, can censure any Member for obeying the chief Magistrate of the Nation: When what is done, is for to preserve the Government, and peace of the Churches.

10. Whither such five persons (so assembled,) can confirm all the aforesaid proceedings, viz. concerning the Observation of Holy daies, the ejection of Mr. Delmey, the suspension of several Members from the Lords Supper, the putting of the Deacons out of the Consistory, and all the Irregularities before mentioned.

These several Quaeres being duely considered; It cannot be disproved (we hope,) but that they comprehend, and contein the whole State, and Substance of all the Differences in dispute between us in the said French Churches. And if by a sober, and Christian Reply thereto, we can be convinced, and confuted, that We are in an Errour, and not justly defended by our Discipline, and former Acts of our Colloquies: We shall willingly embrace those opprobrious Appellations of being factious Rebells against Ecclesiasticall Orders, and to be accompted disturbers, and breakers of the peace of the Churches, (as the Pamphlettors doe term us.) And hereby promise to submit to any Censures, that shall be for that cause, imposed on us by a Colloquie of all the French Churches, legally and rightly to be convened, and assembled, according to our Discipline and Customes. And if by their Judgement We shall be acquitted and justified, We further hope, all Godly, and good men, will esteem it equitable, and conformable to common Justice, That the innocent should not be condemned with the guilty. And i • for the peace, and quiet of our Churches, his Highness, by and with the advice and consent of his Right-honourable privie Councill, do graciously
interpose to redress our grievances, We shall account his Highness's justice to be most acceptable to us, & no waies infringing the order of our Discipline and Government. Which submission of ours, We humbly conceive will satisfie the Christian Reader, how much we desire the Peace, and Order of our Churches; And that if the Opponents cannot convince us, This Refutation of their Pamphlet shall stand for a full and sufficient Vindication of Mr. Delmey, and all others concerned in our Differences, without further Addition, or Supplement.

But by way of Corollary, We shall earnestly request the Candid Reader to consider, with what malignity, and virulence of Spirit the said Mr. Cisner, and Mr. Stouppe, (with some of the London Consistory,) are infected: Who, together with Mr. Payen, Pastour, (one of the five persons, assembled in London, before-mentioned,) and some of the Consistory of Dover, have since the Session of those five persons, in the pretended Colloquie, in August, and September, 1656. particularly attempted to confound the Peace, and Government of that ancient well ordered Walloon-Congregation in Canterbury: And
to that end have advised, and encouraged particular Members thereof, who (being some of them debauched, and scandalous,) have been suspended from the Lords Supper almost ten or eleven years, by Letters, and otherwise; Approveing their gathering of hands, and sending to France for Mr. Jannôn (a Minister,) who upon that call came to Canterbury, and there, (though desired,) he refused to treat with the Consistory of that Church: And the Lords day following, (contrary to the consent of the Major of that Citty,) preached in the morning in one of the English Churches: and in the afternoon, (without any mature deliberation,) elected Elders, and Deacons, (altogether unknown to him for their conversations;) which was such a rash, and inconsiderate Action, as it doth not onely manifest the animosity of the Confederates, but is an absolute Rupture and breach of the good Government of that Church, and all other the French Churches in England.

Whereupon the Walloon Consistory in Canterbury, sent by Letter to advise with the London Consistory: Who refused to answer their Letter, (though entreated by an Elder of their own;) yet nevertheless Mr. Cisner, with Mr. Paul D'Obey (an Elder,) and others
of that Consistory, wrote to those new factious persons, animating, and exhorting them to expedite their proceedings; for that in short time, their new Church (so schismatically erected,) should be acknowledged the Regular Church, and as regular, as their Church in London; as some of those disorderly persons themselves have related in Canterbury. After which counsell, and encouragement, they have hitherto made their progress: and Mr. Jannôn hath setled himself, and his family there, making a Voiage to France to bring them over. In whose absence Mr. Payen of Dover, and the malignant Elder before mentioned, who left London upon his Highness Proclamation, came to Canterbury: And on a Lords day Mr. Payen preached, and administred the Lords Supper to this upstart, disorderly Congregation. And Mr. Jannôn, (at his return from France,) preached at Dover to Mr. Payen's Congregation; and afterwards when he arrived again at Canterbury, an Elder now in Consistory of the French Church in London, being then at Canterbury with his wife, did publickly own the said Mr. Jannôn, and his irregular Congregation. All which actions are directly opposite, and contrary to the express words of an act of Colloquie made in the year, 1646. hereafter specified.

Which combination doth evidently discover the Consistory in London, in their design to corroborate and strengthen their party: whereby not onely to propagate such disorders, and infringe the Government of all the French Churches in England; But also to eject Mr. Philip le Keux, (a godly and faithfull Pastour in Canterbury, as there it hath been reported;) As they have unjustly done by Mr. Delmey in London: For Mr. Jannôn hath uttered in Canterbury, (as others have also said in London,) That it will not be well with the Strangers-Churches, till their English Ministers are expulsed; meaning Mr. Delmey, and Mr. le Keux, being born in England.

These unhappy, and irregular Actions falling out, the Walloon Consistory in Canterbury, (depending their differences,) did write to the Synod of the French Churches in Holland, assembled at Roterdam in September last past, complaining of the great Rent made in that Church by disorderly people, and praying that grave Assembly to recommend a Godly Minister to officiate therein.

Whereupon that grave Assembly took their sad condition into serious consideration: And by their Letters returned, did not
onely bewail the Breach in that Church, but also depute Mr. Stuart Minister, to make a voyage to Canterbury, to be Assistant to Mr. Phillip le Keux, Pastour in that Church, till they should otherwise provide for themselves; Professing that they were thereunto obliged by the communion of Saints. And also the Reverend Moderator, Monsieur De la Riviere, (who signed that Letter in the name of the Synod,) commiserating the Condition of that Church, which he termed antient, and composed of the best party of the Walloons in Canterbury, declared in that Synod, that if he were able to travell, he would willi • gly cross the Seas to endeavour the good of that Church: Whose Christian expressions so far prevailed, That divers Ministers voluntarily profered their service, even to absent themselves from their Families for some time, to assist that Church, if the Synod would depute them. Upon which Mr. Stuart being elected by the major part of the Synod was ordered to be sent over lately for that service of Love, and is expected accordingly.

This Relation is here inserted, that the Reader may the better understand, and consider how Mr. Cisner, Mr. Stouppe, and others of their party doe demean themselves; And whither their comportment be in that
Christian-like manner, and corresponding with that pious, and reverend Assemblie's in Holland; who vouchsafed spontaneously, and freely their compassionate Letter, and assistance; Albeit they were not under the the same Obligations of Church Government: When as, Mr. Cisner, Mr. Stouppe, and others of their party, refused to answer the said Walloon Consistorie's Letter; and under hand, and indirectly some of them incited and instigated Mr. Jannôn, and his scandalous, and schismaticall Faction; Although by our Discipline, and Church Government they were engaged, (for all the Churches unity, and peace,) to the contrary.

Wherefore considering all the evil Consequences of the premisses; and withall that all our French Churches were likely to be destroyed; The Consistory in Canterbury have unanimously Petitioned his Highness, (no other means being left them;) Informing him of the premisses, and their sad condition, occasioned by Mr. Cisner, Mr. Stouppe, and some of the London Consistory. And for proof thereof they have annexed a Certificate from the Major of Canterbury; certifying his dislike of the factious proceedings of the said disorderly persons,
with some particulars thereof; and also an Affidavit of four credible persons made before him. Which Petition, and papers remain before his Highness, and his Council; From whom, that Consistory humbly pray, and wait for relief.

Moreover, (since that Occurrences doe daily, most sadly evene,) We shall further enarrate, and declare to the Reader, whose too much tired patience We crave to respect with candour, and benevolence; That Mr. Cisner, and Mr. Stouppe, with some others of their adherents, assiduously, and diligently persist in their Machinations, and unworthy complotting against the said Walloon Church in Canterbury: In as much as on the 5 October last, Mr. Payen, Minister in Dover, (one of the five persons sitting in the said pretended Colloquie, before complained against; together with his before-mentioned malignant Elder,) came then to Canterbury, and had much private discourse with Mr. Jannôn, and several members of his schismaticall Faction, and the next day returned to Dover: But the day after that, Mr. Payen came again to Canterbury, and with Mr. Jannôn immedietely set forward for London, (it being then given out in Canterbury, that Mr. Jannôn should preach
in the French Church in London, and be approved of by the Coetus; Where the next day being Thursday, they arrived; On which very night, a Consistory of the French Church in London, was called to meet the next morning early, who met accordingly; and, (as some of them have reported,) the occasion was to order, that Mr. Jannôn might preach in that Church the Lords day following in the morning; Which was by them debated, and Mr. Stouppe went to Mr. Jannôn's lodging, (being neer to Mr. Cisner's house,) desiring him to preach; Who promised so to doe, and was expected accordingly by many people, who went purposely to hear him: But by the indisposition of his health, (as it is said,) he sent the Man of the house where he lodged, to Mr. Stouppe intreating an excuse.

By which passage, (although perhaps by some it may be lightly accounted,) yet the Reader we hope will be convinced, that Mr. Cisner, and Mr. Stouppe, with their correspondents doe still animate, and abett Mr. Jannôn and his irregular upstart faction, to the great disquiet and distraction of the said Walloon Church in Canterbury; and manifestly design also the trouble and perplexity of the Church in London; So as, (if they
could,) they would by their evill practices, and Confederacies utterly eradicate, and subvert the whole Government of all the French Churches in England: Howsoever they pretend, (but meerly by Collusion,) their assiduity, and care to maintein the Discipline thereof. Which will be more clearly discovered, and unveiled; If the Reader be pleased to consider the 105. Article, Entred, Thursday the third of September, 1646. of the twenty seventh Colloquie assembled in London in May preceding; translated out of French, viz.

For prevention of Schismes, and many other disorders which do slide into our Churches, The Company doth declare; that if there be any Minister, either amongst Us, or without, that doth establish Assemblies apart there, where a Church is already constituted; because it doth overthrow the maintenance of the holy Ministery, and the relief of the Poor, and openeth the door to all sorts of Sects, and Opinions: They are Infringers of the Discipline, and Disturbers of the rest of the Churches. Therefore if such an one be amongst Us, he is subject to a Censure, untill a Deposition. If he be from without, he is lyable to be deposed,
and unworthy of the holy Ministery: And the principall Authors, and Fomentors of such irregular Assemblies shall be dealt withall according to the rigour of the Discipline.

If the severity of this Article be not popositively, and directly against the Interpellation, and Interfaring of Mr. Jannôn, in attempting to establish a new Assembly at Canterbury; whereby himfelf, and his Fomentours are subject to the rigour and censures of our Discipline; let the Reader be pleased impartially to define, and adjudge.

And now to return to the proper business of our selves; And thereby, (as far as we can,) to manifest, and illustrate the truth, and our Innocence, with our ardent desires of mutuall satisfaction, and peace: We held it expedient to address our selves to the Consistory of the Dutch by Letter: Whereby we desired them to give us Christian satisfaction, As by the matter it self to them proposed in the words following, will evidently appear, viz.

body.p: YOu may be pleased to remember, That the 13 of this instant month, Seven Fathers of Families of the French Church London, for themselves, and others, appeared at your Church before your Consistory, and presented a Paper: A Copy whereof, (as was desired,) was delivered the next day to Mr. Nicholas Corsellis; And conteined, as followeth.

1. If a Coetus of the Stangers-Churches in London, have any power over any particular Church, or member thereof, or any difference therein; after an Appeal made to a Colloquie of their own Churches? And if any such practice hath been since the constitution of Colloquies.
2. If such power in a Coetus be pretended! If then the Dutch have any power over the French, or the French over the Dutch, by the Discipline, or Acts of Colloquies of either Church.

3. If the Colloquies of the Churches of either Language have heretofore ordered, That an Appeal may be made from either Colloquie to a Synod of both Nations? And if such an Appeal be approved of by the Discipline of either Churches? And what Directions, or formalities are there prescribed for the making of such an Appeal?

Which being presented, our Members withdrew: And after a long debate by your Consistory, They were called in. And Mr. Calandrain, your Moderator, was pleased to answer our two first Quaeres, Negatively; That the Dutch had no power over the French, nor the French over the Dutch: And the third he answered affirmatively: That Synods of both Colloquies had power: But could not declare the formality, how it should be constituted; Or when Synods atteined that power, And in fine gave no satisfactory Answer, concerning the Discipline of either Church: concluding that we should propose that question to the Coetus: Because the Certificate, in dispute, was given by the Coetus to the French Consistory.

Hereupon the twentieth of this Moneth, we attended the Coetus, and proposed that third Question unto them: To which Mr. Cisner, (their Moderatour,) replyed; That we ought to have addressed to the French Consistory first; and our appearing there was irregular: And therefore the Coetus could give no other answer. Which to Us seemed very strange: Since we pursued Your own direction: And the matter properly concerned not the French, but your selves, and the Italian Church: And we professed, That if a Synod had any such power; (of which we desired Information,) We should render Obedience thereto; Not yet knowing, that they had any such faculty, or power. We also prayed the Coetus to vouchsafe Us a Coppy of the Certificate signed by some of your selves, and others of the Italian Church; Which was delivered to the French Consistory: Whereto Mr. Cisner replyed, That it was not the Custome of the Coetus to give Copies.

By which equivocall Answer, We have not Justice done Us, either for matter, or manner; For, (as to the matter,) You ought to have clearly answered our last Question, as well as the two others; For
that, You with the Italian Church had given a Certificate, to the purpose mentioned in the Petition of the French Consistory to his Highness the Lord Protector. And for the manner, You have permitted Mr. Cisner, Mr. Stouppe, and others to Vote in their own Cause; Which is contrary to natural, and common reason. Wherefore We again humbly request You to do Us right, by answering our said third Question, and justifiing your Certificate: Or else, We shall conclude, that You cannot in Justice defend it: Which we have good cause to beleeve You cannot do; Because Mr. Host, and Mr. Corsellis, (two eminent Members of Your Consistory,) have denyed the same: And in your Answeres to Our two former Questions, You have disproved a part of that Certificate. And as You are Ministers, and Elders, appointed to rule according to the Discipline, We intreat You to give Us Christian Satisfaction in Our desire: Otherwise You will give Us manifest occasion to suspect, that some of Your Consistory, have been instrumentall to foment, and chearish the troubles of our Churches. Which for our Vindication, We shall be necessarily engaged to publish to the World, (but with much grief, and
remorse;) In case you shall not answer our just, and requisite Proposall: For which we wait, and attend your result, Remaining

closer.signed:
Your Christian Brethren, and Friends, in all the Bonds of Amitie, and love. Signed by,
John Jurin Senior.
Daniel Fervacques.
Isaac Le Gay.
Peter Jurin.

div.p:
The twenty fourth day of September last, the four Subscribers of this Letter, attended the Dutch Consistory, and delivered it to Mr. Van Cewlen, (one of the Elders;) who carried it into that Consistory; And after some attendance, returned them their Answer, That they understood they desired an Answer to the third Question, Therefore they must apply themselves to the Coetus. Which was all the answer they could get to the said Letter. Whereby the Reader may be advertised; whither the Dutch Consistory do not apparently reveal themselves to be Patrons, and Fautors of our Differences: And were Agents in the Design of the French Consistory to subvert our Government; By insisting to promote, and erect a Coetus, or Synod of both Nations to be our judge, contrary to our antient and fundamentall Discipline. Yet however the seventh day of October also last past, two of the aforenamed Subscribers of that Letter, did in a private and affectionate manner, desire Mr. William Cross, (one of the Elders of the Dutch Church,) that he would be pleased to propound to their Consistory once more, that satisfaction might yet be rendered to the Fathers of Families of the French Church: So far forth, that if by any Rules, or directions,
(extant with them,) any power be rightfully invested in the Synod by the Discipline of the French Churches, (in the said Letter mentioned,) to order, or enact any finall Sentence in the matters before by us remonstrated; We should then upon full Evidence, and Demonstration thereof, willingly acquiesce, and yield due obedience thereunto. But thereunto we could obtein no more Satisfaction, then when the said Letter was presented to the Dutch Consistory.

Wherefore to leave them without all excuse, or pretence of Evasion, the said four Subscribers on Wednesday 14 October last, (being an ordinary Consistory day,) addressed again to the French Consistory; Informing, That they had atended the Coetus, for their Answer to the said third Question, concerning an Appeal to a Synod of both Nations, and the Formality of such Appeal: Whose answer was, That the appearing of the Fathers of Families was irregular: But wherein we understand not! However those Subscribers were come to them for their answer thereunto; Desiring them, (if they could,) to maintein and prove, That there ought to be a Synod, either by the Discipline of the French Churches, or by some Act of Colloquie: And if so, we
should render obedience thereto: After which they withdrew, and soon after were called in; and for answer that Consistory said, That they had other business before them, and therefore could give no Answer till eight daies were past. Whereto the Subscribers replyed, that if they intended to return Us to a Coetus, It might be done the next day, being the usuall day for the Dutch Consistorie's meeting; Intreating them to abridge their time, and give us their Answer in four daies; For that some of the Dutch Elders had already affirmed, That a Synod of both Nations had no power, but by consent of parties. VVherefore after a second withdrawing, that Consistory would appoint no other time; nor gave they Us any direction further to attend them.

Yet notwithstanding, being desirous to have satisfaction to the said third Question, the said four Subscribers of the aforesaid Letter, at the eight daies end, being the 21. of the said Moneth of October last past, attended again upon the Consistory of our Church: who being admitted to their presence, Mr. Cisner, (their Moderatour,) entred into a long discourse; Declaring to them, (amongst other things,) that in the year, 1593. Mention was made of a Synod; And that since that time, there had been 5. or 6. Synods; whose formality
of convention was, by the Assembling of the Colloquies of both French, and Dutch Churches, together at one and the same time: And thereupon exhorted those Subscribers to submit thereto. Unto which the Subscribers replyed, that they came not thither to be informed in that particular; for that they well knew, there had been Synods: And they well approved either a Synod, or Coetus, in their proper nature, and order, and according to the ends, for which they were intended by the Discipline of our French Churches: hoping that the Consistorie would not deem them to be persons, that opposed them contrary to their usage in our Churches. But Mr. Cisner's allegations were short in answering our Question: Which was, Whither any publick, or private person, who had been censured by a Colloquie of our Churches, had power or permission to appeal to a Synod of both Nations? And if so, Then by what Examples positively to be produced by the Consistory it could be manifested, when it was so done, and with what formality? And so the Subscribers desired a Copy of such their Testimonies, or Precedents. Whereupon Mr, Cisner (finding, that he could not make out any such thing to satisfie the four Subscribers,) did at length plainly confess, That
the Appeals to such a Synod were left at liberty. Albeit the French and Dutch Consistories, would averr it to be part of the Discipline, as by the Petition of the French Consistory to his Highness, appeareth. Wherefore the Subscribers desired them again to produce their Testimonies and Precedents. Which they said, they had, as also others unanswerable; to be made known in due time. And would give no further Answer, or satisfaction. Therefore the Subscribers proposed, that the Consistory would appoint two or three of themselves, to meet with the like number of the Fathers of Families, whereby mutual satisfaction might be given in a fair Discourse, and Treaty; And that, as they were a Consistory, and Governours of the Church, and obliged to seek the peace thereof, they would procure a right understanding of the Point in Question. Whereupon, (Being first withdrawn, and the Consistory falling into debate of that proposition,) the Subscribers were answered by two of their Members, (sent out on purpose,) That their Company had no more to say to them; Thereby intimating their aversion, and backwardness to treat; or communicate upon any other subject; and so dismissed them in that manner, as if they intended to have no more conference at all with them.

These mediations, and transactions being had by Us, We intreat the Reader to consider, what equivocations, and Sophismes have been used to us, in being transferred from one to another: That when we desire satisfaction to 3 Questions, the Dutch Consistory by their own power answer to two of them; And as to the third direct us to the Coetus. And when we come to the Coetus, (consisting of Dutch French, and Italians;) then they decline, and say, (in generall termes onely,) our coming is Irregular. After this we address to the French Consistory; And they take upon them, (without a Coetus,) to answer us, but deferr it to another time; And then they give no satisfactory Answer at all, nor produce their Testimonies, nor accept of any proposition, whereby mutuall Satisfaction might be rendred. And now; whither we have not done our duty, we appeal to all indifferent, and unbyassed Censures. But we shall palpably, and demonstratively refute, and reprove that assertion in the French Consistorie's Petition, grounded upon the Certificate of the Coetus; If we first suppose, that the manner or formality of appealing to a Synod of both Nations, must of necessity be known to some persons or other. And for our parts we averr, that we never heard, that any one being
censured by a Consistory, or Colloquie of the French Churches, had any power, or was permitted to appeal to a Synod of both Nations, or that any such practice was ever amongst us. But secondly, we shall prove the contrary by Precedent, and Acts of Colloquies, made by all the Deputies of the French Churches in England. Especially (to instance in one, amongst many others which we can produce,) We shall vouch, the seventeenth Article of the twenty sixt Colloquie, assembled in London, in the year, 1644. Whereby it appears, That Mr. De Laune, Minister in Norwich, had a difference with Mr. D'assegny (another Minister there at that time;) And before that business was entred upon, Mr. De Laune prayed that Assembly, that his business might have been examined, and debated in the Assembly of both Colloquies, of the French and Dutch Churches. Whereto, (as in Article 18.) the Advise of the Colloquie was, that the business concerned directly, and particularly the French Churches,: And themselves would take cognisance (of the matter.) To which Articles we referr our selves, and desire (as being most remarkable,) that it may be observed, that the French Colloquie did determine that difference themselves; Notwithstanding that at the very same
time, that Mr. De Laune made his request as aforesaid, the Dutch Colloquie was then sitting in London: And afterwards a Synod did ass • mble; But Mr. De Laune was not permitted to appeal to them. Nor did the Dutch pretend any power, or jurisdiction in that business or any other, wherein the French were solely interessed.

And we doe find by our Book of Colloquies, that there have been not above sixe Synods in almost 80. years: whose assembling was, for the consulting, and advising together in affairs of a generall nature, which publikely concerned both Nations, viz. As to petition the King, or Parliament, or Privie Councill, upon some matters, or other universally concerning all Strangers in generall under their protection; or for to settle, and secure their Discipline severally, according to the forme thereof, when it was opposed by the Bishops, or otherwise drawn into Question. At which times of their meetings; It is very observable, that the severall Colloquies of either Churches did sit distinctly, and apart by themselves to act, debate, determine and regulate all matters, and differences concerning the Members of each Nation; although they did so sit in Synod, at the same time for generall concernments, as aforesaid.

Now before we can conclude this Treatise, We conceive it necessary, (for avoiding of all disputes, and removing all probable Scrupules, that may perhapps be made, or arise,) to answer two main Objections, viz.

1. It may be objected, Why will not Mr. Delmey, and the Fathers of Families submit their differences to a Synod, composed of the Deputies of all the Churches, both Dutch and French in England; Being they are both incorporated by one Patent, and thereby under one Ecclesiasticall government?

In answer whereto for the Readers satisfaction, We admit it to be true, that we are both under one Patent; yet nevertheless that Patent leaveth each Nation to its proper, and peculiar Ecclesiasticall Discipline, as before is specified; And for almost eighty years we have exercised a severall, and distinct Discipline for Church Government: And albeit the French have ever agreed with the Dutch in the main Essentials; yet they have alwaies differed in some Circumstantials: As for Example: The Dutch Churches have alwaies observed Holy daies: And for many years the French have not. The Dutch Ministers preach uncovered: And the French covered.
The Dutch Churches administer the Lords Supper the last Lords day, at the end of every two Moneths; and the French Churches the first Lords day in every Moneth, &c. Whereby it is evident, the exercise of our Discipline is various, and apart, and the power of either Churches independent one of another, as the Dutch have confessed.

Again, (as the state of Mr. Delmey's, and our Affairs consists,) we cannot rationally be conceived to be so stupid, and obtuse, as to submit our differences to the decision of the Dutch Churches, conjoined with our own in Synod; Since that the Dutch Consistory in London have made themselves considerable parties therein, and been instrumental to effect (if they could,) that our differences might be determined by a Coetus; wherein they would chiefly predominate. And moreover, It is a usage amongst them, that when a Colloquie of the Dutch Churches assembleth in London (as of late years for the most part they doe;) Some Elders of that Church in London do serve, as Deputies for other absent Churches: Whereby there would be a greater number of Dutch Elders of the Church in London, (who are partially concerned, and interessed as aforesaid,) than can be thought just, or equitable in reason, or good Conscience.

Lastly, the Dutch Elders have confessed, as before in our Letter to their Consistory is expressed, that they have no power, but by consent of parties: Wherefore to consent to them is but to undo, and unravel, what hath been by ful assent of al parties condescended to already in referring all differences to his Highness, and the English Divines, as aforesaid; & so thereby 2 whole years transactions for the peace, and quiet of our Churches should be rendred fruitless, and ineffectuall; And his Highness's great care, and the pains of those Reverend Divines be totally made null, and inefficacious. But as things now stand, a Colloquie of the French Churches cannot be properly constituted, so as to be conjoined with the Dutch; for that (besides they having been heretofore affronted by the French Consistory in London,) many of them that are now capable to sit in Colloquie, are incompetent, being engaged on one side or other, and others are not capable, being either not rightly qualified, or else have acted so contrary to the Discipline of our Churches, that they ought not to be admitted. 2. It may be objected, Why have Mr. Delmey, and the Fathers of Families, applyed to the Magistrate, for help, and Relief: When as no Magistrate hath any power to intermeddle in Ecclesiastical Censures? which is the matter, now in question between them, and their Consistory.

To answer the same, We say; That We suppose the Reader will not expect from us, that we should definitively conclude, what the Magistrate's power is one way, or other; As is objected: In respect of our own private Capacities, and the difficulty of the Argument. For as much as we well know, that some do concede to the Magistrate too much Authority, and power to interpose in Ecclesiasticall affairs; and others grant him too little; And there be some, that will allow him none at all. However we well know, that by many Examples in the Holy Scriptures, the Princes, and Rulers in Judah, and Jerusalem, did for the Reformation, and good Government of the Church, extend their power to Ecclesiasticall matters; As did Asa, Hezekiah, Josiah, Nehemiah, and others

But as to the matter of Fact, touching our Application to his Highness, on the behalf of Mr. Delmey, and our selves. We hope it cannot be denyed; That as the Maxime is, Whosoever hath power to give hath also to dispose, as he pleaseth: And as our Ancestours, being but Strangers in this Nation, could not erect at first our Church, without the grant and Licence of Edward the sixt: So then it is but of naturall consequence
to be admitted, That the King, and his Successors should have the common Patronage, and Protection of what was by them granted; When ever their aid, & assistance was prayed in an extrordinary Case. Which hath happened to us; In asmuch, as that before we ever petitioned his Highness; we had tryed all other ordinary waies and means whatsoever with the Consistory, as by this Treatise is obvious to all men. And the Reverend English Divines, have reported to his Highness, that they conceive, that as well by the Charter of Edward the sixt, as by several Acts of our Colloquies, his Highness is intituled to the cognisance of the business; For by that Patent, no Minister could be inducted into the Strangers Churches in London, unless he was first approved of by that King, or his Successours.

And the Fathers of Families, petitioned his Highness in behalf of Mr. Delmey, and themselves, as being all of them obstructed, and hindred from enjoying their just Privileges, and advantages, according to their Discipline and Government, granted them by the Liberty of that Patent; to wit, Mr. Delmey, being defeated of his • ight, • s Pastor lawfully chosen, and of his st •• end, and maintenance in recompence of his Charge: and
the Fathers of Families being suspended from the Lords Supper, for no other Cause, but for defending Mr. Delmey's innocence, and petitioning for Justice, and their rights to his Highness: Both which were denyed them by their Consistory.

And we have done no more in Petitioning his Highness, than the Consistory themselves have done; onely We differ in the Manner: For We pray his Highness to grant us in effect, an establishment of our Antient Governement by Colloquies: And the Consistory have proposed to, and prayed him, that a new Ecclesiasticall form of Government might be superinduced, and set up by a Coetus, or Synod. So that both of us by our own Petitions have admitted power in his Highness, to settle us in peace, and confirm that Discipline, which of right doth belong to the French Churches in England. And how can it be otherwise done, but by his Highness's examination, and interposition in those Ecclesiasticall matters now in question, whereby to find out and discover, who hath, or who hath not transgressed; and thereby to understand the difference, and to give relief to the oppressed according to justice.

But to clear the objection fully, We shall
positively assert, that his Highness, (notwithstanding the premisses,) is rightfully intituled to the determination and Judgement of our Case; For as much as all parties have absolutely consented thereunto; Which if the Consistory of London have the confidence to deny, We shall prove, as followeth.

1. Mr. Stouppe, 6. Elders, and 4. Deacons, (representing the whole Consistory,) submitted before his Highness, (As before is mentioned,) That all differences should be referred to the Colloquie of the Deputies of all the Churches, called by his Highness's, Order; And in case they could not determine them, then that ten, or twelve Godly Divines, (as his Highness should appoint,) should hear and decide the same, (if they could;) And if they could not, that his Highness should finally and conclusively settle, and adjudge the same: As by his Highness's last Order of Reference to the Divines (afore recited,) may appear.

1. This may be plainly manifested, in that the Consistory of London elected, and impowered their Deputies to attend that intended Colloquie, called by his Highness's order, aswell as the other Churches.

2. After that Assembly could not regularly constitute, the said Consistory
submitted to the English Divines, and attended them with seven several writings and Papers, Thereby making their Defence to all the matters in question, as the said Divines have reported.

3. The said five persons, (taking upon them so irregularly the pretended form, and power of a Colloquie,) did by the Instigation of the Consistory of London themselves, Censure them for their Submission before his Highness, to the hearing and decision of the English Divines. As by the translated Copy of their formall Act, taken in French by Mr. Delmey, 27. August, 1656. (Being then made,) and read by him unto them in presence of severall Fathers of Families may appear, viz.

That the Company having considered the acquiescence of both parties, aswell of the Consistory, as of the Fathers of Families to the Proposition of his Highness, touching the ten or twelve English Ministers, have condemned the one, and the other; It being greatly prejudicial to the authority of our Colloquies.

This formall Act is very worthy of due Consideration; Mr. Cisner, and his Elders, (b • ing present at, and causeing the making thereof against themselves, and the Fathers
of Families,) without the knowledge at first of Mr. Delmey, and the Fathers of Families; As the said five persons can sufficiently justifie.

And now whither We have not amply, and satisfactorily answered, and confuted the said Objections, by reason, proof, and positive Demonstration, We submit to the Reader's acceptance, and approbation. And if nevertheless, the said Consistory shall alledge, that at length they protested in writing against their former submission to the English Divines; We acknowledge, that we have heard so much, and that the Reverend Divines have certified the same to his Highness; But We affirme, That the Consistory did it, after they had presented their Papers of Defence to his Highness, and three Moneths after their first submission before his Highness at Whitehall, before specified. So that we conceive, they cannot be rationally excused by that pretence: For that, as their Protest was made too late; So was it also vain, and ridiculous, and ought so to be accounted and reputed; for as much as they have at severall times presented three, or four Petitions, touching the Differences in question to his Highness, and his Councill; Thereby admitting their power to give redress, and settle the same. All which we intreat the Courteous Reader
specially to take notice of, and well to weigh and consider our aforesaid Answers to the said Objections; for that the Pamphlettors have in their Appendix, (in the very conclusion thereof,) professed; That they cannot consent, that Mr Delmey should be judged by English Ministers; as having never been practiced in our Churches, and being wholly contrary to the privileges, which they have enjoyed since their Establishment here. Which profession, and assertion of theirs we request the Reader signally to remark, whither the same be to be credited; Their Submission being so plainly proved, and when as the same hath been done both by English, and Scotch Ministers, as before is mentioned: And whither their disingenuity doth not aswell appear, in this very last Clause of their Appendix; as it doth also in the very first page of their Pamphlet; wherein they so covertly, and obscurely mention; that the French Church in London hath been troubled almost two years by Mr. Delmey; which we have so clearly, and apparently refuted. And being in all their Pamphlet they have only suggested, but not proved any one allegation; but on the contrary asserted that, which the Dutch Consistory have denyed, as we have before fully proved; It •… efore upon the whole matter submitted
to the Judgement of the Reader, whither their •… amphlet deserves to be credited, or any part •… ereof, being so clearly refuted and disproved 〈◊〉 the body and parts of this our Treatise.

Upon the whole Enarration, and Declara
•… on of which Corollary, and Additions, •… e entreat the Courteous Reader finally •… o judge betwixt Mr. Cisner, Mr. Stouppe, and •… heir party of the London Consistory, and Mr.
•… elmey, and Our selves (the Fathers of Fa
•… ilies, and other Members of the French-Church in London;) Whither (they having •… ade such a violent, and precipitate Irru
•… tion upon our Discipline and Government, •… nd still persist to evert, and dissolve it, and •… aving fomented others so to do in another Church,) they have not professedly, and of set-purpose oppressed, and injured Mr. Delmey, and our selves, as also that Walloon Consistory of Canterbury. And in that respect we hope, (notwithstanding that the Dutch, and French Consistories decline to give us satisfaction,) That We shall be further vindicated, and absolved from their Imputations, and calumniations against us; And our Innocence, and Integritie be justified, and defended by the Reader's candid and benevolent Interpretation; To which We have most unwillingly, and with much grief, and reluctance
been necessitated to flie, and retire; As i •… our Epistle We have alledged. And were i •… not to confine our selves to as much brevity as the necessary Circumstances of the matte •… require, We could haue super-added a mor •… prolixe Relation of our Grievances; Whic •… that the Reader might not be wearied, an •… defatigate, We have omitted. And for tha •… Interruption, and Diversion, We have hereb •… occasioned to his Christian patience, VV •… most earnestly entreat him, (out of hi •… Christian Compassion, and Sympathie to and with Us in our sad Distractions,) charitably to remitt, and preterlapse.
